children: Overview

In this lesson, we unify the algebraic and geometric views of linear systems through the powerful equation **$ A\vec{x} = \vec{b} $**. You’ll learn how matrix-vector multiplication works, what it means for **$ \vec{b} $** to be in the **span** of the columns of **$ A $**, and how this determines whether a solution exists.
This perspective — called the **column view** — is fundamental to understanding linear algebra beyond rote computation.
By the end of this lesson, you will:

children.children: Interpret the equation **$ A\vec{x} = \vec{b} $** as a **linear combination of columns**.
Determine whether **$ \vec{b} $** lies in the **span** of the columns of **$ A $**.
Understand the **existence** and **uniqueness** of solutions in terms of column span and linear independence.
Connect solution sets of **$ A\vec{x} = \vec{b} $** to vector spaces and translation of subspaces.
Recognize when a matrix **$ A $** can map some **$ \vec{x} $** to any desired **$ \vec{b} $** in **$ \mathbb{R}^m $**.

children: 1. The Equation **$ A\vec{x} = \vec{b} $**: Two Views
We’ve seen linear systems row by row. Now, let’s flip the perspective: view them **column by column**.
Given a matrix **$ A $** and vectors **$ \vec{x} $**, **$ \vec{b} $**, the equation:
A\vec{x} = \vec{b}
asks: Can we combine the **columns** of **$ A $** using the entries of **$ \vec{x} $** to get **$ \vec{b} $**?
Matrix-Vector Multiplication as Linear Combination
Let:
Then **$ A\vec{x} $** is:
x_1 \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix} + x_2 \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 5 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}
✅ So solving **$ A\vec{x} = \vec{b} $** means: *Find weights **$ x_1, x_2 $** such that the linear combination of **$ A $**’s columns equals **$ \vec{b} $**.*
The vector **$ \vec{b} $** must lie in the span of the columns of **$ A $** for a solution to exist.
2. The Column Space of **$ A $**
The **column space** of a matrix **$ A $**, denoted **$ \text{Col}(A) $**, is the **span of its column vectors**.
It answers the question:
For which vectors **$ \vec{b} $** does **$ A\vec{x} = \vec{b} $** have a solution?
Answer: **Exactly when** **$ \vec{b} \in \text{Col}(A) $**.
Example: When **$ \vec{b} $** Is in the Span
Let:

A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & -1 \\ 2 & 3 \end{bmatrix},\quad
\vec{b} = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \end{bmatrix}
Are the columns of **$ A $** enough to span **$ \vec{b} $**? Try to solve:
x_1 \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix} + x_2 \begin{bmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \end{bmatrix}
This leads to a system that has a solution (**$ x_1 = 2, x_2 = -1 $**), so **$ \vec{b} \in \text{Col}(A) $**.
3. Existence vs. Uniqueness
Two key questions about **$ A\vec{x} = \vec{b} $**:

children.children: **Uniqueness**: Is there *only one* solution? **$\Leftrightarrow$** Are the columns of **$ A $** **linearly independent**?

children: These two questions are independent:

children.children: **$ \vec{b} $** is not in the column space

children: 4. The General Solution Structure
Suppose we’re solving **$ A\vec{x} = \vec{b} $** (non-homogeneous).
If there is **at least one solution** **$ \vec{x}_p $** (a **particular solution**), then the **complete solution** is:
\vec{x} = \vec{x}_p + \vec{x}_h
where **$ \vec{x}_h $** is **any solution** to the homogeneous equation **$ A\vec{x} = \vec{0} $**.
Geometrically: the solution set is the **homogeneous solution space** (a line/plane through origin), **shifted** by **$ \vec{x}_p $**.
Example

Let **$ A\vec{x} = \vec{b} $** have a particular solution **$ \vec{x}_p = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} $**, and suppose the null space is spanned by **$ \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix} $**. Then the general solution is:
\vec{x} = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} + t\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix},\quad t \in \mathbb{R}
This is a **line** in **$ \mathbb{R}^2 $** — not through the origin, but parallel to the null space.
5. When Does **$ A\vec{x} = \vec{b} $** Have a Solution for **Every** **$ \vec{b} $**?
A matrix **$ A $** (size **$ m \times n $**) can reach **every** vector in **$ \mathbb{R}^m $** **if and only if** its columns **span** all of **$ \mathbb{R}^m $**.
This requires:

children.children: At least **$ m $** columns (i.e., **$ n \geq m $**) — but more importantly,
The **pivot columns** must cover all **$ m $** rows — meaning **$rank = m $**.

children: Such a matrix has a **wide or square** shape and **full row rank**.
💡 If **$ \text{Col}(A) = \mathbb{R}^m $**, then **$ A\vec{x} = \vec{b} $** is solvable for **any** **$ \vec{b} $** — though not necessarily uniquely.
6. Summary
The equation **$ A\vec{x} = \vec{b} $** is more than algebra — it’s a **geometric membership test**:

children.children: ✅ **Solution exists** **$\Leftrightarrow$** **$ \vec{b} $** is in the **span of the columns** of **$ A $**
✅ The column space determines **what outputs** **$ A $** **can produce**

children: Mastering this view unlocks deeper topics: invertibility, rank, least squares, and eigenvectors.
